full_text:
Configuring Search

Lesson
objectives

¢ Describe how Guidewire applications enable
users to search for entities

« Extend SearchCriteria entities

* Modify ClaimCenter search screens

¢ Modify contact search

| ClaimCenter enables two kinds of search Gi

¢ Search within ClaimCenter * Vendor/contact search
* Claims, Activities, Checks, Recoveries, * Searches address book application
Bulk Invoices, Users, Groups * ContactManager or third-party application
+ Vendors and other contacts

* Related to service requests

=| sscrersbeck'~ Dashboard Team Aaminiation Search Address Book For Vendors (=

| Demonstration G

Searching for entities

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Search within ClaimCenter Gi

¢ ClaimCenter server creates a SearchCriteria object from choices in the Ul

¢ Uses the SearchCriteria object to query the database

ClaimCenter UI ClaimCenter Server : 4 ClaimCenter Database

= | Search Claims

BEE Search Results

Claim Search Screen Search Criterion object

Vendor or contact search G
* ClaimCenter server forms a SearchCriteria object from choices in the Ul
¢ Extracts search terms from SearchCriteria object

¢ Passes search terms to address book application via Web Services

ClaimCenter Server

ClaimCenter UI

©) Search Address Book For Vendors
BB caret Tce conscatonow |

Contacts Table

H Vendor Search Screen E Search Criterion object

Address Book

| Search criteria object Gi

¢ Virtual, non-persistent entity with no underlying database table
¢ Virtual fields match actual fields in target database

. Implemented by file configuration/config/search/search-config. xml

YB configuration
Y Greontig
> Ba Contact
> eDemtty Names
> CY Extensions
> CP Localizations

search

Gh claimcontact-search-configxm!
sh search-configam!

iG search-configasd

servlet

| search-config.xml Gi

¢ Defines all searches that can be performed in ClaimCenter

* Consists of one SearchConfig element and numerous sub-elements

tes Search-config.xml
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
<SearchConfig
amlns :xsi="http: //www.w3.org/2001/xMLSchema-instance"
xsi :noNamespaceSchemaLocation="search-config.xsd"
version="1">

¢ IMPORTANT: DO NOT CREATE ADDITIONAL SearchConfig TAGS
* This is NOT supported by Guidewire

| search-config.xml elements Gi

* SearchConfig: Defines the search criteria available in the application
* CriteriaDef: Specifies the mapping from one search criteria entity to the target
entity on which to search

* Criterion: Specifies matching between a column (field) on the search criteria entity and the
target entity

+ Use only to match values in a single column of the same type in the target entity

* CriterionChoice: Defines specialized properties in the search criteria that can match
against a number of target fields

* Option: Describes a single choice within a CriterionChoice definition

* ArrayCriterion: Specifies that the search query uses a simple join against an array entity

| CriteriaDef sub-element Gi

Defines a mapping between a key data entity and a search criteria entity

Basic syntax:
<CriteriaDef entity="name" targetEntity="name">
<sub-elements/>
</CriteriaDef>
Sub-elements can include criterion, CriterionChoice, and ArrayCriterion
WARNING: Guidewire does not support creation of new criteriaDef elements

WARNING: Guidewire strongly recommends not removing existing criteriaDef
elements

<CriteriaDef entity="ClaimInfoCriteria" targetEntity="ClaimInfo">
<Criterion property="ClaimNumber" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="PolicyNumber" matchType="eq"/>
</CriteriaDef>

| Criterion sub-element Gi

¢ Defines a simple one-to-one relationship between a criteria entity attribute and a
target entity attribute
¢ Basic syntax:
<Criterion property="attributename"
targetProperty="attributename"
matchType=" type" />
* property is the name of the property on the criteria entity
* targetProperty is the name of the property on the target entity

* Only use if it is different from the value of property
<Criterion property="ClaimNumber" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="AssignedToUser" targetProperty="AssignedUser" matchType="eq"/>
<Criterion property="CreatedByUser" targetProperty="CreateUser" matchType="eq"/>

| matchType tag Gi

* matchType determines how the target property is matched to the criteria property
« Seven main choices:

* contains

<CriteriaDef entity="Address" targetEntity="Address">

sed <Criterion property="City" matchType="startsWith"/>

* ge <Criterion property="CityKanji" matchType="startsWithCaseSensitive"/>
<Criterion property="State" matchType="eq"/>

* gt <Criterion property="PostalCode" matchType="startsWith"/>
<Criterion property="Country" matchType="eq"/>

ele </CriteriaDef>

elt

* startsWith

| CriterionChoice sub-element Gi

¢ Allows a single criterion to match against one of several columns in the target, as
chosen by the user

« For example, the Date criterionChoice element on the Advanced Claim Search screen

allows users to search for one date: the Loss date, the Reported date, the Closed date, or the
Creation date

* Basic syntax:

<CriterionChoice property="attributename"

init ="valueOrExpression"> Search For Date

Loss date
<option label="displaykey"

<none>

targetProperty="targetColumn"/>
. . . Reported date
</CriterionChoice> Closed date

* May have one or more option elements | Creation date _|

CriterionChoice sub-element example: Gi
DateCriterionChoice

<CriterionChoice property="DateCriterionChoice"
init="DateCriterionChoice.SearchType = TC_CLAIM; DateCriterionChoice.DateSearchType =

TC_FROMLIST; DateCriterionChoice.DateRangeChoice = TC_N365; DateCriterionChoice.ChosenOption =
&quot ;Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate&quot ;">

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate" targetProperty="LossDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.ReportedDate" targetProperty="ReportedDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CloseDate" targetProperty="CloseDate"/>

<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CreateDate" targetProperty="CreateTime"/>

</CriterionChoice>

¢ The label tag must refer to a display key

¢ The targetProperty attribute is required coon cocone ‘ccsdate
when adding new Options © since Last 365 days .
From @
* Including all option subelements on new to oo

CriterionChoice subelements

Optional init attribute of CriterionChoice Gi

<CriterionChoice property="DateCriterionChoice”
init="DateCriterionChoice.SearchType = TC_CLAIM; DateCriterionChoice.DateSearchType = TC_FROMLIST;
DateCriterionChoice.DateRangeChoice = TC_N365; DateCriterionChoice.ChosenOption = équot;Java.Criterion.Option.Claim
+ LossDate&quot ;">
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.LossDate" targetProperty="LossDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.ReportedDate" targetProperty="ReportedDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CloseDate" targetProperty="CloseDate"/>
<Option label="Java.Criterion.Option.Claim.CreateDate" targetProperty="CreateTime"/>
</CriterionChoice>

In this example, the init attribute specifies how to restrict the date field

* The user can restrict the date range either through a typelist of preset ranges
(such as next 30 days) or through a specific start and end date

* The init attribute sets the values

| ArrayCriterion (1 of 3) Gi

¢ Instructs ClaimCenter to add a simple join against an array entity to the search
query
« For example, the Claim entity has an array of Officials
* So, you could add an ArrayCriterion that searched for officials of a given name or type
¢ Basic syntax:
<ArrayCriterion property="somename"
targetProperty="someTargetProperty"
arrayMemberProperty="propertyToMatchOnAnArrayMember" />

<ArrayCriterion
property="0fficials"
targetProperty="0fficials"
arrayMemberProperty="0fficialType"/>

| ArrayCriterion (2 of 3)

All attributes are required
Supports equality matching only
* Therefore, you cannot specify a matchType attribute on ArrayCriteria
Is not used in the base application
* Most commonly used for joins to custom entities
The arrayMemberProperty cannot allow duplicate values

* Otherwise, the same target instance might appear multiple times in the search results

| ArrayCriterion (3 of 3) Gi

Two indexes must be present on the array table.
« The first must be on the foreign key back to the main table and your chosen arrayMemberProperty
* The second must be on the same two properties but in the reverse order
(arrayMemberProperty first)
<index name="ind1" unique="true">
<indexCol name ="Claim" keyposition="1"/>
<indexCol name="0fficialType" keyposition="2"/>
</index>
<index name="ind2" unique="true">
<indexCol name="0fficialType" keyposition="1"/>
<indexCol name="Claim" keyposition="2"/>

</index>

SearchCriteria entities Gi

¢ Every criteriaDef sub-element references by its ae
name a SearchCriteria entity Faut—_perentagedec

¢ These entities are created by Guidewire

« Do not create a new one

¢ When adding a new column to search for, you must
add the column to the searchcriteria

To search for a simple column on the target entity, create a boiny | AechivaDetncs atone
column

To search for a column which is a foreign key on the target
entity, create a foreign key

To search for a column which is a typekey on the target
entity, create a typekey

To search for an array on the target entity, create an array

| Demonstration G

Configuring search criteria

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question G

,~ — What is the underlying table for a search criteria entity?

¢
4
¢

sSesoeooce SSeS Seee5b505

Answer a

,~ — What is the underlying table for a search criteria entity?

¢
74
¢ The correct answer is there is none; it is a virtual, non-persistent entity

se sSeSo SSeS SSeS e ee sSHeS

| Configuring search in the UI

Is pretty much like configuring anything else in the Ul,

except...

| Search using a search panel

« Requires many complex properties
« Recommended you use existing search panels (and pages)

« If you must create a new search panel/page consult Guidewire Services

<SearchPanel
coriteriaNane="Searchcriteria”

.cabase. IQueryBeanResultélt;Regionégt;"

pickValue="CheckedValues"/>
</Toolbar>
</PanelRef>
</searchPane1>

Search fields Gi

¢ Appear in input sets in search panels

« Value for a search field must be a property of the appropriate SearchCriteria entity

{Term.Claim.Proper} #| ClaimSearch...

)

Text Input
¥ Basic properties
editable true
id* ClaimNumber
label DisplayKey. get ("JSP.ClaimSearch.Claims.ClaimNumber")
required false

value* ClaimSearchCriteria.ClaimNumber

| Required search fields

¢ Required search fields (or groups of
fields) are set up by Guidewire

« You cannot add required search fields

* Attempting to do so is not supported by
Guidewire

¢ You should not remove required fields

« May have unexpected results

Search Activities

Claim # |

Assigned To Group <none>

Include Child Groups Yes No
Assigned To User <none>

Created By <none>
External Owner <none selected>

4

| Finally... G

Regenerate the SOAP and Java APIs.

1

a

. Open a command window.
2. Navigate to ../ClaimCenter.

3.

4. lf you have added any new fields to entities (other than the virtual

Run the command gwb genJavaApi.

SearchCriteria entities), also regenerate the Data Dictionary
« Run the command gwb genDataDict

Restart the ClaimCenter server.

6. Test your changes.

| Demonstration G

Modifying search screens

click here

Note: The demonstration opens a new tab in your browser. When the demonstration ends, the
original course launch window appears. Return to this window to continue this presentation.

Question G

,- — What sub-elements can a CriteriaDef element have?

¢
4
¢

sSesoeooce SSeS Seee5b505

Answer

,~ — What sub-elements can a CriteriaDef element have?

¢
74
¢ The correct answers are:

* Criterion
* CriterionChoice
¢ ArrayCriterion

se sSeSo SSeS SSeS e ee sSHeS

Question G

,~ — What is special about the input widgets on a search page?

¢
4
¢

sSesoeooce SSeS Seee5b505

Answer a

,~ — What is special about the input widgets on a search page?

¢

74
¢ The correct answer is they represent properties, not of the target entity, but of its
related Search Criteria entity.

se sSeSo SSeS SSeS e ee sSHeS

| Configuring contact search Gi

¢ To add a field to contact search you 5. Add ContactManager search
must configure both ClaimCenter capability in ClaimCenter.
and the address book application * ContactSearchCriteria.etx

+ ContactSearchMapper.gs

Steps (with ContactManager):

. * ContactSearchResultMapper.gs
1. In ContactManager, add a field as

already shown. 6. Test your changes.
2. Add new search capability in ¢ For more details see the Contact
ContactManager (see next slide) Management Guide

3. Restart ContactManager.

4. Refresh the web services in
ClaimCenter.

| To add new search capability in ContactManager Gi

1. Extend the ABContactSearchCriteria entity.

2. In search-config.xml, map aBContactSearchCriteria extensions to the ABContact
entity.

3. Modify the contact search criteria detail view so that new search criteria can be
specified.

4. Optionally modify the contact search results list view to display information about
your specified field.

5. Regenerate the Java and Soap APIs.

6. Restart the ContactManager server.

Question G

_~ — After adding a new search criterion to an existing search page, what
oo must be done?

sSesoeooce SSeS Seee5b505

Answer a

_~ — After adding a new search criterion to an existing search page, what
oo must be done?
¢

The correct answer is:
Regenerate the SOAP and Java APIs.
Redeploy and restart the ClaimCenter server.
